an3.40:1.1.eng: “There are, mendicants, these three things to put in charge.

an3.40:1.3.eng: Putting oneself, the world, or the teaching in charge.

an3.40:1.4.eng: And what, mendicants, is putting oneself in charge?

an3.40:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an3.40:1.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

an3.40:1.6.pli: ‘na kho panāhaṃ cīvarahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
an3.40:1.6.eng: ‘I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe,

an3.40:1.7.pli: Na piṇḍapātahetu, na senāsanahetu, na itibhavābhavahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
an3.40:1.7.eng: almsfood, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.

an3.40:1.8.pli: Api ca khomhi otiṇṇo jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto.
an3.40:1.8.eng: But I was swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I was swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

an3.40:1.9.pli: Appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethāti.
an3.40:1.9.eng: And I thought, “Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.”

an3.40:1.10.pli: Ahañceva kho pana yādisake kāme ohāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito tādisake vā kāme pariyeseyyaṃ tato vā pāpiṭṭhatare, na metaṃ patirūpan’ti.
an3.40:1.10.eng: But it would not be appropriate for me to seek sensual pleasures like those I abandoned when I went forth, or even worse.’

an3.40:1.12.pli: ‘āraddhaṃ kho pana me vīriyaṃ bhavissati asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggan’ti.
an3.40:1.12.eng: ‘My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, mindfulness shall be established and lucid, my body shall be tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind shall be immersed in samādhi.’

an3.40:1.13.pli: So attānaṃyeva adhipatiṃ karitvā akusalaṃ pajahati, kusalaṃ bhāveti, sāvajjaṃ pajahati, anavajjaṃ bhāveti, suddhaṃ attānaṃ pariharati.
an3.40:1.13.eng: Putting themselves in charge, they give up the unskillful and develop the skillful, they give up the blameworthy and develop the blameless, and they keep themselves pure.

an3.40:1.14.eng: This is called putting oneself in charge.

an3.40:2.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is putting the world in charge?

an3.40:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an3.40:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

an3.40:2.3.pli: ‘na kho panāhaṃ cīvarahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
an3.40:2.3.eng: ‘I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe,

an3.40:2.4.pli: Na piṇḍapātahetu, na senāsanahetu, na itibhavābhavahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
an3.40:2.4.eng: almsfood, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.

an3.40:2.5.pli: Api ca khomhi otiṇṇo jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto.
an3.40:2.5.eng: But I was swamped by rebirth, old age, and death, by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I was swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

an3.40:2.6.pli: Appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
an3.40:2.6.eng: And I thought, “Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.”

an3.40:2.7.pli: Ahañceva kho pana evaṃ pabbajito samāno kāmavitakkaṃ vā vitakkeyyaṃ, byāpādavitakkaṃ vā vitakkeyyaṃ, vihiṃsāvitakkaṃ vā vitakkeyyaṃ, mahā kho panāyaṃ lokasannivāso.
an3.40:2.7.eng: And now, since I’ve now gone forth, I might have sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts. But the population of the world is large,

an3.40:2.8.pli: Mahantasmiṃ kho pana lokasannivāse santi samaṇabrāhmaṇā iddhimanto dibbacakkhukā paracittaviduno.
an3.40:2.8.eng: and there are ascetics and brahmins who have psychic power—they’re clairvoyant, and can read the minds of others.

an3.40:2.9.pli: Te dūratopi passanti, āsannāpi na dissanti, cetasāpi cittaṃ pajānanti.
an3.40:2.9.eng: They see far without being seen, even by those close; and they understand the minds of others.

an3.40:2.11.pli: ‘passatha, bho, imaṃ kulaputtaṃ saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno vokiṇṇo viharati pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehī’ti.
an3.40:2.11.eng: “Look at this gentleman; he’s gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, but he’s living mixed up with bad, unskillful qualities.”

an3.40:2.12.pli: devatāpi kho santi iddhimantiniyo dibbacakkhukā paracittaviduniyo.
an3.40:2.12.eng: And there are deities, too, who have psychic power—they’re clairvoyant, and can read the minds of others.

an3.40:2.13.pli: Tā dūratopi passanti, āsannāpi na dissanti, cetasāpi cittaṃ jānanti.
an3.40:2.13.eng: They see far without being seen, even by those close; and they understand the minds of others.

an3.40:2.15.pli: ‘passatha, bho, imaṃ kulaputtaṃ saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno vokiṇṇo viharati pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehī’ti.
an3.40:2.15.eng: “Look at this gentleman; he’s gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, but he’s living mixed up with bad, unskillful qualities.”’

an3.40:2.17.pli: ‘āraddhaṃ kho pana me vīriyaṃ bhavissati asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggan’ti.
an3.40:2.17.eng: ‘My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, mindfulness shall be established and lucid, my body shall be tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind shall be immersed in samādhi.’

an3.40:2.18.pli: So lokaṃyeva adhipatiṃ karitvā akusalaṃ pajahati, kusalaṃ bhāveti, sāvajjaṃ pajahati, anavajjaṃ bhāveti, suddhaṃ attānaṃ pariharati.
an3.40:2.18.eng: Putting the world in charge, they give up the unskillful and develop the skillful, they give up the blameworthy and develop the blameless, and they keep themselves pure.

an3.40:2.19.eng: This is called putting the world in charge.

an3.40:3.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is putting the teaching in charge?

an3.40:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an3.40:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

an3.40:3.3.pli: ‘na kho panāhaṃ cīvarahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
an3.40:3.3.eng: ‘I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe,

an3.40:3.4.pli: Na piṇḍapātahetu, na senāsanahetu, na itibhavābhavahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
an3.40:3.4.eng: almsfood, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.

an3.40:3.5.pli: Api ca khomhi otiṇṇo jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto.
an3.40:3.5.eng: But I was swamped by rebirth, old age, and death, by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I was swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

an3.40:3.6.pli: Appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethāti.
an3.40:3.6.eng: And I thought, “Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.”

an3.40:3.7.pli: Svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhīti.
an3.40:3.7.eng: The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

an3.40:3.8.pli: Santi kho pana me sabrahmacārī jānaṃ passaṃ viharanti.
an3.40:3.8.eng: I have spiritual companions who live knowing and seeing.

an3.40:3.9.pli: Ahañceva kho pana evaṃ svākkhāte dhammavinaye pabbajito samāno kusīto vihareyyaṃ pamatto, na metaṃ assa patirūpan’ti.
an3.40:3.9.eng: Now that I’ve gone forth in this well explained teaching and training, it would not be appropriate for me to live lazy and heedless.’

an3.40:3.11.pli: ‘āraddhaṃ kho pana me vīriyaṃ bhavissati asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggan’ti.
an3.40:3.11.eng: ‘My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, mindfulness shall be established and lucid, my body shall be tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind shall be immersed in samādhi.’

an3.40:3.12.pli: So dhammaṃyeva adhipatiṃ karitvā akusalaṃ pajahati, kusalaṃ bhāveti, sāvajjaṃ pajahati, anavajjaṃ bhāveti, suddhaṃ attānaṃ pariharati.
an3.40:3.12.eng: Putting the teaching in charge, they give up the unskillful and develop the skillful, they give up the blameworthy and develop the blameless, and they keep themselves pure.

an3.40:3.13.eng: This is called putting the teaching in charge.

an3.40:3.14.eng: These are the three things to put in charge.

an3.40:4.1.eng: There’s no privacy in the world,

an3.40:4.2.eng: for someone who does bad deeds.

an3.40:4.4.eng: whether you’ve lied or told the truth.

an3.40:5.1.eng: When you witness your good self,

an3.40:6.1.eng: The gods and the Realized One see

an3.40:6.2.eng: the fool who lives unjustly in the world.

an3.40:6.3.eng: So with yourself in charge, live mindfully;

an3.40:6.4.eng: with the world in charge, <j>be alert and practice absorption;

an3.40:6.5.eng: with the teaching in charge, <j>live in line with that teaching:

an3.40:6.6.eng: a sage who tries for the truth doesn’t deteriorate.

an3.40:7.2.eng: one who strives reaches the end of rebirth.

an3.40:7.4.eng: that sage is determined by nothing at all.”

an3.41:1.1.pli: “Tiṇṇaṃ, bhikkhave, sammukhībhāvā saddho kulaputto bahuṃ puññaṃ pasavati.
an3.41:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when three things are present, a faithful gentleman brims with much merit.

an3.41:1.3.pli: Saddhāya, bhikkhave, sammukhībhāvā saddho kulaputto bahuṃ puññaṃ pasavati.

an3.41:1.4.pli: Deyyadhammassa, bhikkhave, sammukhībhāvā saddho kulaputto bahuṃ puññaṃ pasavati.
an3.41:1.4.eng: when a gift to give is present,

an3.41:1.5.pli: Dakkhiṇeyyānaṃ, bhikkhave, sammukhībhāvā saddho kulaputto bahuṃ puññaṃ pasavati.
an3.41:1.5.eng: and when those worthy of a religious donation are present.

an3.41:1.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ sammukhībhāvā saddho kulaputto bahuṃ puññaṃ pasavatī”ti.
an3.41:1.6.eng: When these three things are present, a faithful gentleman brims with much merit.”

an3.42:1.1.eng: “There are three grounds, mendicants, by which a person with faith and confidence can be known.

an3.42:1.3.pli: Sīlavantānaṃ dassanakāmo hoti, saddhammaṃ sotukāmo hoti, vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgo payatapāṇi vossaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato.
an3.42:1.3.eng: They like to see ethical people. They like to hear the true teaching. And they live at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

an3.42:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi ṭhānehi saddho pasanno veditabbo.
an3.42:1.4.eng: These are the three grounds by which a person with faith and confidence can be known.

an3.42:2.1.eng: They like to see ethical people;

an3.42:2.2.eng: they want to hear the true teaching;

an3.42:2.3.eng: they’ve driven out the stain of stinginess:

an3.42:2.4.eng: that’s who’s called an individual of faith.”

an3.43:1.1.pli: “Tayo, bhikkhave, atthavase sampassamānena alameva paresaṃ dhammaṃ desetuṃ.
an3.43:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, taking three reasons into consideration provides quite enough motivation to teach Dhamma to another.

an3.43:1.3.pli: Yo dhammaṃ deseti so atthappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammappaṭisaṃvedī ca.
an3.43:1.3.eng: When the teacher understands the meaning and the teaching.

an3.43:1.4.pli: Yo dhammaṃ suṇāti so atthappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammappaṭisaṃvedī ca.
an3.43:1.4.eng: When the audience understands the meaning and the teaching.

an3.43:1.5.pli: Yo ceva dhammaṃ deseti yo ca dhammaṃ suṇāti ubho atthappaṭisaṃvedino ca honti dhammappaṭisaṃvedino ca.
an3.43:1.5.eng: When both the teacher and the audience understand the meaning and the teaching.

an3.43:1.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo atthavase sampassamānena alameva paresaṃ dhammaṃ desetun”ti.
an3.43:1.6.eng: Taking these three reasons into consideration provides quite enough motivation to teach Dhamma to another.”

an3.44:1.3.pli: Yo dhammaṃ deseti so atthappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammappaṭisaṃvedī ca.
an3.44:1.3.eng: When the teacher understands the meaning and the teaching.

an3.44:1.4.pli: Yo dhammaṃ suṇāti so atthappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammappaṭisaṃvedī ca.
an3.44:1.4.eng: When the audience understands the meaning and the teaching.

an3.44:1.5.pli: Yo ceva dhammaṃ deseti yo ca dhammaṃ suṇāti ubho atthappaṭisaṃvedino ca honti dhammappaṭisaṃvedino ca.
an3.44:1.5.eng: When both the teacher and the audience understand the meaning and the teaching.

an3.44:1.6.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi ṭhānehi kathā pavattinī hotī”ti.
an3.44:1.6.eng: These are the three situations in which conversation flows.”

an3.45:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these three things are recommended by astute true persons.

an3.45:1.5.eng: and taking care of your mother and father.

an3.45:1.6.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi paṇḍitapaññattāni sappurisapaññattānīti.
an3.45:1.6.eng: These are the three things recommended by astute true persons.

an3.45:3.1.eng: These are the things recommended by the good,

an3.45:3.4.eng: will enjoy a world of grace.”

an3.46:1.1.pli: “Yaṃ, bhikkhave, sīlavanto pabbajitā gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharanti.
an3.46:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when ethical renunciates are supported by a town or village,

an3.46:1.2.pli: Tattha manussā tīhi ṭhānehi bahuṃ puññaṃ pasavanti.
an3.46:1.2.eng: the people there brim with much merit in three ways.

an3.46:1.4.eng: By way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.46:1.5.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, sīlavanto pabbajitā gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharanti.
an3.46:1.5.eng: When ethical renunciates are supported by a town or village,

an3.46:1.6.pli: Tattha manussā imehi tīhi ṭhānehi bahuṃ puññaṃ pasavantī”ti.
an3.46:1.6.eng: the people there brim with much merit in these three ways.”

an3.47:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the conditioned has these three characteristics.

an3.47:1.3.pli: Uppādo paññāyati, vayo paññāyati, ṭhitassa aññathattaṃ paññāyati.
an3.47:1.3.eng: Arising is evident, vanishing is evident, and change while persisting is evident.

an3.47:1.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi saṅkhatassa saṅkhatalakkhaṇānī”ti.
an3.47:1.4.eng: These are the three characteristics of the conditioned.”

an3.47:2.3.pli: Na uppādo paññāyati, na vayo paññāyati, na ṭhitassa aññathattaṃ paññāyati.
an3.47:2.3.eng: No arising is evident, no vanishing is evident, and no change while persisting is evident.

an3.47:2.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi asaṅkhatassa asaṅkhatalakkhaṇānī”ti.
an3.47:2.4.eng: These are the three characteristics of the unconditioned.”

an3.48:1.1.pli: “Himavantaṃ, bhikkhave, pabbatarājaṃ nissāya mahāsālā tīhi vaḍḍhīhi vaḍḍhanti.
an3.48:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, great sal trees grow in three ways supported by the Himalayas, the king of mountains.

an3.48:1.3.pli: Sākhāpattapalāsena vaḍḍhanti, tacapapaṭikāya vaḍḍhanti, pheggusārena vaḍḍhanti.
an3.48:1.3.eng: The branches, leaves, and foliage; the bark and shoots; and the softwood and heartwood.

an3.48:1.4.pli: Himavantaṃ, bhikkhave, pabbatarājaṃ nissāya mahāsālā imāhi tīhi vaḍḍhīhi vaḍḍhanti.
an3.48:1.4.eng: Great sal trees grow in these three ways supported by the Himalayas, the king of mountains.

an3.48:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, saddhaṃ kulapatiṃ nissāya anto jano tīhi vaḍḍhīhi vaḍḍhati.
an3.48:2.1.eng: In the same way, a family grows in three ways supported by a family head with faith.

an3.48:2.3.pli: Saddhāya vaḍḍhati, sīlena vaḍḍhati, paññāya vaḍḍhati.

an3.48:2.4.pli: Saddhaṃ, bhikkhave, kulapatiṃ nissāya anto jano imāhi tīhi vaḍḍhīhi vaḍḍhatīti.
an3.48:2.4.eng: A family grows in these three ways supported by a family head with faith.

an3.48:3.2.eng: in the wilds, the formidable forest,

an3.48:3.4.eng: to become lord of the forest.

an3.48:4.1.eng: So too, when the family head

an3.48:4.6.eng: and those dependent for their livelihood.

an3.48:5.1.eng: Seeing the ethical conduct of the virtuous,

an3.48:6.2.eng: the path that goes to a good place,

an3.48:6.3.eng: they delight in the heavenly realm,

an3.48:6.4.eng: enjoying all the pleasures they desire.”

an3.49:1.1.eng: “In three situations, mendicants, you should be keen.

an3.49:1.3.pli: Anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya ātappaṃ karaṇīyaṃ, anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya ātappaṃ karaṇīyaṃ, uppannānaṃ sārīrikānaṃ vedanānaṃ dukkhānaṃ tibbānaṃ kharānaṃ kaṭukānaṃ asātānaṃ amanāpānaṃ pāṇaharānaṃ adhivāsanāya ātappaṃ karaṇīyaṃ.
an3.49:1.3.eng: You should be keen to prevent bad, unskillful qualities from arising. You should be keen to give rise to skillful qualities. And you should be keen to endure physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, life-threatening.

an3.49:1.4.pli: Imehi tīhi, bhikkhave, ṭhānehi ātappaṃ karaṇīyaṃ.
an3.49:1.4.eng: In these three situations, you should be keen.

an3.49:2.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya ātappaṃ karoti, anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya ātappaṃ karoti, uppannānaṃ sārīrikānaṃ vedanānaṃ dukkhānaṃ tibbānaṃ kharānaṃ kaṭukānaṃ asātānaṃ amanāpānaṃ pāṇaharānaṃ adhivāsanāya ātappaṃ karoti.
an3.49:2.1.eng: It’s a mendicant who is keen to prevent bad, unskillful qualities from arising. They’re keen to give rise to skillful qualities. And they’re keen to endure physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, life-threatening.

an3.49:2.2.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ātāpī nipako sato sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāyā”ti.
an3.49:2.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who is keen, alert, and mindful so as to rightly make an end of suffering.”

an3.5:1.1.eng: “A fool is known by three things.

an3.5:1.3.pli: Ayoniso pañhaṃ kattā hoti, ayoniso pañhaṃ vissajjetā hoti, parassa kho pana yoniso pañhaṃ vissajjitaṃ parimaṇḍalehi padabyañjanehi siliṭṭhehi upagatehi nābbhanumoditā hoti.
an3.5:1.3.eng: They ask a question irrationally. They answer a question irrationally. And when someone else answers a question rationally—with well-rounded, coherent, and relevant words and phrases—they disagree with it.

an3.5:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bālo veditabbo.
an3.5:1.4.eng: These are the three things by which a fool is known.

an3.5:2.1.pli: Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito veditabbo.
an3.5:2.1.eng: An astute person is known by three things.

an3.5:2.3.pli: Yoniso pañhaṃ kattā hoti, yoniso pañhaṃ vissajjetā hoti, parassa kho pana yoniso pañhaṃ vissajjitaṃ parimaṇḍalehi padabyañjanehi siliṭṭhehi upagatehi abbhanumoditā hoti.
an3.5:2.3.eng: They ask a question rationally. They answer a question rationally. And when someone else answers a question rationally—with well-rounded, coherent, and relevant words and phrases—they agree with it.

an3.5:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito veditabbo.
an3.5:2.4.eng: These are the three things by which an astute person is known.

an3.50:1.1.pli: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato mahācoro sandhimpi chindati, nillopampi harati, ekāgārikampi karoti, paripanthepi tiṭṭhati.
an3.50:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a master thief with three factors breaks into houses, plunders wealth, steals from isolated buildings, and commits highway robbery.

an3.50:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro visamanissito ca hoti, gahananissito ca hoti, balavanissito ca hoti.
an3.50:1.3.eng: A master thief relies on uneven ground, on thick cover, and on the powerful.

an3.50:1.4.eng: And how does a master thief rely on uneven ground?

an3.50:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro nadīviduggaṃ vā nissito hoti pabbatavisamaṃ vā.
an3.50:1.5.eng: It’s when a master thief relies on inaccessible riverlands or rugged mountains.

an3.50:1.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, mahācoro visamanissito hoti.
an3.50:1.6.eng: That’s how a master thief relies on uneven ground.

an3.50:2.1.eng: And how does a master thief rely on thick cover?

an3.50:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro tiṇagahanaṃ vā nissito hoti, rukkhagahanaṃ vā rodhaṃ vā mahāvanasaṇḍaṃ vā.
an3.50:2.2.eng: It’s when a master thief relies on thick grass, thick trees, a blind spot, or a large forest grove.

an3.50:2.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, mahācoro gahananissito hoti.
an3.50:2.3.eng: That’s how a master thief relies on thick cover.

an3.50:3.1.eng: And how does a master thief rely on the powerful?

an3.50:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro rājānaṃ vā rājamahāmattānaṃ vā nissito hoti.
an3.50:3.2.eng: It’s when a master thief relies on rulers or their chief ministers.

an3.50:3.4.pli: ‘sace maṃ koci kiñci vakkhati, ime me rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā pariyodhāya atthaṃ bhaṇissantī’ti.
an3.50:3.4.eng: ‘If anyone accuses me of anything, these rulers or their chief ministers will speak in my defense in the case.’

an3.50:3.5.pli: Sace naṃ koci kiñci āha, tyāssa rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā pariyodhāya atthaṃ bhaṇanti.

an3.50:3.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, mahācoro balavanissito hoti.
an3.50:3.6.eng: That’s how a master thief relies on the powerful.

an3.50:3.7.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tīhi aṅgehi samannāgato mahācoro sandhimpi chindati, nillopampi harati, ekāgārikampi karoti, paripanthepi tiṭṭhati.
an3.50:3.7.eng: A master thief with these three factors breaks into houses, plunders wealth, steals from isolated buildings, and commits highway robbery.

an3.50:4.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tīhi aṅgehi samannāgato pāpabhikkhu khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṃ, bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavati.
an3.50:4.1.eng: In the same way, when a bad mendicant has three factors, they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much wickedness.

an3.50:4.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu visamanissito ca hoti gahananissito ca balavanissito ca.
an3.50:4.3.eng: A bad mendicant relies on uneven ground, on thick cover, and on the powerful.

an3.50:5.1.eng: And how does a bad mendicant rely on uneven ground?

an3.50:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu visamena kāyakammena samannāgato hoti, visamena vacīkammena samannāgato hoti, visamena manokammena samannāgato hoti.
an3.50:5.2.eng: It’s when a bad mendicant has unethical conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.50:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu visamanissito hoti.
an3.50:5.3.eng: That’s how a bad mendicant relies on uneven ground.

an3.50:6.1.eng: And how does a bad mendicant rely on thick cover?

an3.50:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu micchādiṭṭhiko hoti, antaggāhikāya diṭṭhiyā samannāgato hoti.
an3.50:6.2.eng: It’s when a bad mendicant has wrong view, he’s attached to an extremist view.

an3.50:6.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu gahananissito hoti.
an3.50:6.3.eng: That’s how a bad mendicant relies on thick cover.

an3.50:7.1.eng: And how does a bad mendicant rely on the powerful?

an3.50:7.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu rājānaṃ vā rājamahāmattānaṃ vā nissito hoti.
an3.50:7.2.eng: It’s when a bad mendicant relies on rulers or their chief ministers.

an3.50:7.4.pli: ‘sace maṃ koci kiñci vakkhati, ime me rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā pariyodhāya atthaṃ bhaṇissantī’ti.
an3.50:7.4.eng: ‘If anyone accuses me of anything, these rulers or their chief ministers will speak in my defense in the case.’

an3.50:7.5.pli: Sace naṃ koci kiñci āha, tyāssa rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā pariyodhāya atthaṃ bhaṇanti.

an3.50:7.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu balavanissito hoti.
an3.50:7.6.eng: That’s how a bad mendicant relies on the powerful.

an3.50:7.7.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato pāpabhikkhu khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṃ, bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavatī”ti.
an3.50:7.7.eng: When a bad mendicant possesses these three qualities, they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much wickedness.”

an3.51:1.1.pli: Atha kho dve brāhmaṇā jiṇṇā vuddhā mahallakā addhagatā vayoanuppattā vīsavassasatikā jātiyā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
an3.51:1.1.eng: Then two old brahmins—elderly and senior, who were advanced in years and had reached the final stage of life, a hundred and twenty years old—went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an3.51:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te brāhmaṇā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an3.51:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:

an3.51:1.3.pli: “mayamassu, bho gotama, brāhmaṇā jiṇṇā vuddhā mahallakā addhagatā vayoanuppattā vīsavassasatikā jātiyā;
an3.51:1.3.eng: “We brahmins, worthy Gotama, are old, elderly and senior, we’re advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life; we’re a hundred and twenty years old.

an3.51:1.4.eng: And we haven’t done what is good and skillful, nor have we made a shelter from fear.

an3.51:1.5.pli: Ovadatu no bhavaṃ gotamo, anusāsatu no bhavaṃ gotamo yaṃ amhākaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
an3.51:1.5.eng: Advise us, worthy Gotama, instruct us! It will be for our lasting welfare and happiness.”

an3.51:2.1.pli: “Taggha tumhe, brāhmaṇā, jiṇṇā vuddhā mahallakā addhagatā vayoanuppattā vīsavassasatikā jātiyā;
an3.51:2.1.eng: “Indeed, brahmins, you’re old, elderly and senior.

an3.51:2.2.eng: And you haven’t done what is good and skillful, nor have you made a shelter from fear.

an3.51:2.3.pli: Upanīyati kho ayaṃ, brāhmaṇā, loko jarāya byādhinā maraṇena.
an3.51:2.3.eng: This world is led onward by old age, sickness, and death.

an3.51:2.4.pli: Evaṃ upanīyamāne kho, brāhmaṇā, loke jarāya byādhinā maraṇena, yo idha kāyena saṃyamo vācāya saṃyamo manasā saṃyamo, taṃ tassa petassa tāṇañca leṇañca dīpañca saraṇañca parāyaṇañcāti.
an3.51:2.4.eng: But restraint here by way of body, speech, and mind is the shelter, protection, island, refuge, and haven for the departed.

an3.51:3.1.eng: This life, so very short, is led onward.

an3.51:3.2.eng: One led on to old age has no shelter.

an3.51:3.4.eng: do good deeds that bring you joy.

an3.51:4.4.eng: as the good deeds done while living.”
